Whereas neither are these things able to lengthen their liues: for Luk. 12. 15. haue a man neuer so much of them, his life dependeth not thereupon: nor to keepe them from death: for Psal. 49 7, 8, 9. no price can procure any immunitie from it: nor to saue them in death; for Prou. 11. 4. Ezck 7. 19. riches auaile not in the day of wrath: nor to auaile them after death; for there will then be no vse of them. And for men therefore Eccles. 5. 17. to beat their braines so much with thought and care for these things, and Eccles. 4. 8. to take such paines, as so many doe, for the compassing of them, is but Psal. 39. 6. to t • ile and moile about that, that they must leaue to others at length, and to inherite Psal. 49. 17. Eccles. 5. 15. nothing but Ier. 17. 11. Luk. 12. 20. folly and L 〈…〉 s. 5. 16. & 6. 2, 4. vanitie themselues, when others, Psal. 39. 6. Eccl. 6. 2. they know not who, Eccl. 2. 18, 19. inherit the fruit of their labours.

Lastly, this might teach vs not to feare death. S • ultum est timere, quod vitari non potest. P. Syr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Arrian. 1. Epict. l. 1. c. 27. It is a fond thing (saith he) to feare that, that cannot be Vse 4. auoided. A folly it is to trouble & turmoile our selues with feare and care about that, that by no thought or forecast wee can shunne or shift off. But such is death. Differri potest, auserri non potest. Aug. de diuers. 36. Mortem differunt ista, non au •• runt. Idem de verb. Apost. • 8. Delayed it may be, but auoided it cannot be. And Sed etsi tardius quis moritur, nunquid ideò non moritur? As an ancient Father therefore well and wisely aduiseth; Noli timere, quod velis, • olis, e 〈…〉 : id time, quod, si nelueris, non erit. Aug. de diuers. 36. Feare not that, which whether thou wilt or no, will be; feare that rather, which if thou thy selfe wilt not, shall neuer be. That is, feare not this temporall death, the death of thy body, which of it selfe cannot hurt thee, and by no meanes or care of thine can be preuented: but feare that eternall death, the death of thy soule, De hoc verè dici potest, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Wee feare the bodily death, but not the spirituall death, the death of the soule, the death in sinne, and dying in sinne, without which the other cānot hurt. The feare of death troubleth and distracteth much our minds: but the feare of future matters, that are truly fearfull indeed, and but for wch death needednot at al to be feared, doth no more trouble or affect the most, than as if
no such thing were at all, or they were Esse aliquos manes, &c. Nec pueri credunt, nisi qui nondum • relauantur. Iu • enal. Sat. 2. Nemo tam p • e • e 〈…〉 , vt ista •• meat. Sen. epist. 24. babes only that beleeued them.
And thus much for the Generall, that from this third Branch we obserue:
Some Particulars follow; which I will point at rather than insist on.
More specially therefore we may hence further obserue;
First, that in some cases Point. Speciall 1.

p.hi: To liue long is a blessing.

div.p:
It was foretold Abraham, as a fauour, that hee should Gen. 15. 15. die an old man: and it is here recorded that so he did. And it was foretold Eli, as an heauie iudgement that should betide his posterity, that there should 1 Sam. 2. 32. neuer be any old man in his house. Long life, as in the Exod. 20. 12. Ephes. 62. Deut. 4. 1, 40. & 6 2. Law it is promised oft as a blessing: and God where he describeth by the Prophet the flourishing estate of his people, saith, Esai. 65. 20. There shall no more be, Potest & verti, ex eis, vt ad vtrū que tam infantulū quam senem, r •• eratur illud, Qui n • impleat dies suos, quod & Piscatori placet; • iue, cuius dies Deus non impleat, vt Iun. from them, or goe thence, an infant of daies; that is, none of them shall die young or in infants estate; nor any old man that hath not fulfilled his daies; that is, Viuendi sinis est optimus, cum integra mente caeter. s

tura d • ssoluit. 〈◊〉 de sen. liued so long as in course of nature he well might: but the childe shall die an hundred yeares old; that is, he that is now a childe shall liue till he be so many yeares old: (which place the rather I recite & open at large, in regard of some friuolous Vise • is Hieron. in Esai. 65. And, Psal. 55. 23. Hee shall not liue out halfe his daies; that is, In medio dierum suorum tolletur, vt Psal. • 02. 24. halfe the time that he might in the course of nature haue attained to; saith the Psalmist of deceitfull and bloudie men.

The glory of young men is their strength: (saith Solomon) and the beauty of old men is the gray-head. And, Prou. 16. 31. Old age, or the gray-head, is a crowne of glory, that is,

Secondly, It is a blessing to liue to see posteritie, especially to liue to see withall Gods blessing vpon it. Psal. 128. 1. Blessed is the man that feareth God (saith the Psalmist) Psal. 128. 6. For (among other things, though it
come last, yet not the least) he shall liue to see his childrens children, (that which is recorded also, as a part of Iob 42. 16. Reason 3. Iobs happinesse) and peace upon Israel.

Long life in these respects therefore may well be deemed a blessing.
Secondly, we may hence obserue, that it is

p.hi: A great mercy of God to haue a good old age.

div.p: It is a mercy more than ordinary for men at those yeeres to be kept free in some good measure, though not from such weaknesse as the decay of nature necessarily importeth, yet from such aches, and paines, and grieuances, and diseases, and annoiances, as that age is wont commonly to be annoied and pestered with.

to haue it at that age, wherein most men are wont to finde a much more than vsuall want of it? Thirdly, obserue wee hence, that there is a kinde of

not so much, I say, an Quosdam subit eadem videndi saciendique sati • tas, & vitae non odium, sed fastidium. Sen. ep. 24. irkesomnesse, and tediousnesse,

Cic. de sen. a satietie and fulnesse; when a man, though not weary of a thing, yet he hath his Vixi quantum satis er at: mortem plenus expecto. Sen. epist. 62. fill, so much as he desireth, of it; to the godly especially; for I finde not the phrase vsed in the word but of them onely; as of Abraham here, of Gen. 35. 29. Isaak, of Iob 42. 17. Iob, of 2 Chron. 24. 15. Iehoiada, of 1 Chron. 23. 1. Dauid, of whom it is said also, that he died 1 Chron. 29. 28. Reason 1. with a good gray head, full of daies and riches, and honour.
Now this satietie and fulnesse of life commonly befalleth such;

First, when some speciall promises of God haue beene made good to them, or some speciall Omnino rerū omnium satietas vitae facit satietatem. Vitae autem satietas tempus maturum mortis assert. Cic. de sen. blessings of God enioyed by them, correspondent to their owne desires. So Simeon, when he had liued so long (Luke 2. 26. which it was foretold him he should doe) as to see our Sauiour in the flesh, he hath euen enough of this life, he desireth not now to liue an houre longer. Luke 2. 29, 30. Lord (saith he) now lettest thou thy seruant depart in peace; since that mine eyes haue once seene thy saluation, my Sauiour, and the Sauiour of all mankind. So Iacob, when he saw his sonne Ioseph againe, whom he had Gen. 37. 33, 35. & 42 36, 38. giuen vp for dead and gone long agoe, not aliue only, but in honour, and not him alone, but his issue too; Gen. 46. 30. Let me now die; (saith he) I haue liued long enough; I desire life now no longer; since I haue seene thy face, and that thou art yet aliue. For Gen. 48. 11. I made full account neuer to haue seene thy face; and behold God hath made me see thy seed.

Non acerbum iam iudicant viuere, sed supersluum. Senec. epist. 24. seemeth to be now here no further work for them. Act 13. 36. Dauid (saith he) when he had serued his set time by God assigned him, slept. And the Apostle Paul, as Philip. 1. 24, 25. Ita Martinus decumbens; Domine, si adhuc populo tuo sum necessarius, nō recuso laborem, &c. Seuer. epist. 3. & B • rn. ser. de Mart. he was content to stay longer in the flesh for the good of the Philippians, and the furtherance of their faith, then he desired otherwise to doe: so hee saith on the other side, that Act. 20. 24. his life was not deare to him, he cared not how soone he laid it downe, if so be that he had fulfilled but the course of his ministery, and that his worke it were once at an end.
The Vse of which seuerall Points in a word, may be,

First of the two former, to admonish old men, and such more specially as through the goodnesse of Vse 1. God enioy a commodious and comfortable time of it, free from many such griefes as they heare others of their yeares oft complaine of, to acknowledge Gods great mercy and goodnesse to them therein; as Psal. 91. 16. in lengthening out their life, and satisfying them with a greater number of daies then others ordinarily attaine vnto, by means whereof they may liue to see those brought vp vnder them, and bestowed by them, that are of their charge, and whom God hath here blessed them with: so Psal. 103. 5. in freeing of them from such annoiances, as are vsually attendants of that age, and which might make their continuance here the more tedious and vncomfortable to them: And

But let vs rather herein striue to be affected as Gods Saints are, especially when it hathpleased God
to blesse vs with long life, with many yeeres more, than the greater number of folke are wont to attaine to; Id agendum est, vt satis vixerimus. Sen. epist. 23. Vt satis vixerimus, nec anni, nec d • es facient, sed animus. Idem epist. 62. labour to finde and feele in our selues this satiety and fulnesse of life; and be willing and content to leaue it, when God shall please to call for it, though no speciall affliction or paine enforce thereunto, not Fastidio illis esse cepit vita. And hitherto also of the third Particular, to wit, time when he died.
The fourth and last followeth, and that is whither hee went when hee died; whereof the Text saith here, that
He was gathered to his people; and in another place of him, that

And there is nothing more frequent and common in Scripture than these and the like phrases vsed of persons deceassing, that 1 King. 2. 10. & 11 43. & 14. 30. & 15. 8, 24. they sleepe with, Gen. 15. 15. they goe to, Gen. 35. 29. & 49. 33. Num. 20. 24, 26. & 27. 13. & 31. 2. Deut. 32. 50. they are gathered vnto, either their people, that is, their countrimen, or their ancestors, for that is, Act. 13. 36. Point. Generall 4. their Fathers. So that,

p.hi: Men, when they die, they goe to their people, to their 〈◊〉 Fathers.

div.p: That which may well be vnderstood two waies; and the Holy Ghost might well therin aime at both, because both goe vnder one generall, and the phrase as it may fit either, so Statum mortuorum in genere. Vnde dieu • t Hebr. Qui moritur, ambulat per viam, per quam ambularunt patres cius. Oleast. it may well include both.

Cic. offic. l. 1. buried in the bowels of some beast: since that, as Solomon saith, Eccles 3. 10. all goe to one common place; all returne againe to their dust.
Secondly, in regard of the Soule.

First De commun • generis humani (quoad vitam futuram) societate. Calu 〈…〉 . in Generall: because it departeth hence indefinitely into another world, not proper and peculiar, as he said
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Plut. de superst •• . Speciall. each one did when hee slept, but
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . An bo 〈…〉 . lib. 3. cap. 6. common and generall: it goeth hence to the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Anár. in Apoc. c. 63. Dicunt animas corpore liberatas 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 petere. i. licum qui non videtur. Ambr. de bon. mort. c. 10. Vide Platon. in Phaedone. vnseene world, as the Heathens termed it, or to the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Qued Christian • seculum futurum, Iudaei s • c • uum animarum d • cunt. Brought. in Symbol. & S •• indler. lexic. Pentaglot. world of Soules, as the Hebrew Doctors call it; to that other world, (including both Heauen and Hell) in generall, that is the Congregation House of Soules, as the Graue is of Corpses: As Augelum tuiis simulans se Satanas, non Samuel. Aug. ad Simplic. l. 2 q. 3. & de wirab. l. 2. 6. 11. the supposed Samuel told Saul, (though he meant not, nor intended it so to be taken, that Saul should be in the same speciall state or place that Samuel was then in, when he died) I Sam. 28. 19. To morrow shalt thou be with me; that is, in the other world, wherein both thou and I, and all other good and bad are after decease.

Secondly, more specially; the Soules of Gods Saints and seruants may well be said to go to their people S • v definit 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Greg. Nyss. in Macrin. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Theophyl. in Luc. 16.
and their Fathers, when they die; Ex Hebraeorum sententia Pet. Mar. tyr, & Paraeus. because they goe to that peculiar place, where all their godly Country-men and Ancestors are; to the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Heb. 12. 23. Q 〈…〉 m 〈◊〉 Doctores 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈…〉 . Che • adam. alphab. mystic. c. 1. Congregation house (as the Apostle termes it) of the First-borne, and of the Spirits of the Iust. Nor doth it hinder, but that of Abraham it may so also be vnderstood, albeit that both his Country-mē, the most, it may be of them, and his Ancestours also, many of them, might be idolaters, as Iosh. 24 2. himselfe also at first was; since that many yet no doubt of both those rankes, both were pious, while they liued, and went to God, when they died: Besides that, wel also may they all be termed and stiled Ruth. 1. 16. his people, or country-men, though little of kinne to him otherwise, that were the people, while they liued, of the same God that he serued: Yea as well might Eorum filij dieimur, quorum fidem & mores • mitamur. Orig 〈…〉 Ezik. hom. 4. & 6. Omnes hi matorcs tui sunt, si te illis dignum ges. seris. Sen. epist. 44. all the faithfull that went before him, be termed his Fathers, whether he were lineally and carnally descended of them or no, as Mat. 3. 6. Rom. 4. 16, 18. Gal. 3. 29. all the faithfull that came after him, are termed his sonnes.

p.hi: But to hasten to an end:

div.p:
First, this may serue to strengthen vs against the feare of death, or of what shall become of vs when we are dead: Since that, as Ambulat per viam, per quam ambulauerunt pa • res c • us. Hebr. ex Psal. 49. 19. O 〈…〉 st. sup. Vse 1. we goe not any strange way when we die, such as none haue gone before vs, but a beaten path, that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Iosh. 23. 14. 1 King 2. 2. all, euen good, haue gone; so we goe not to any strange place, where either none are already, or none that we haue any acquaintance withall; but we goe to our Christian friends, to our religious Fore-fathers,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Antiphan. St • b. cap. 124. to a place, where we shall
meet againe with all those, that wee Consecuturi prae misimus. Senec. ad Marc. c. 19 Eô cito peruenturi, qu • illi peruenerint. Idem ep. 63. 2 Sam. 11. 23. sent from hence before vs, hauing deceased in the faith. It is that indeed that much troubleth men and women many times, when they are enforced to trauell into strange countries, and to change the places of their wonted and ancient abode; to fore-thinke, what an vncouth thing it wil be, to come among a strange people, where they know none, and none know them. It would haue troubled Iacob not a little to haue remoued into Aegypt, had he not beene Gen. 45. 58. & 46. 3, 4. sure to finde Ioseph there. But the godly need not be troubled with any such thoughts, when they are to remoue hence: For they shall goe to their owne people, their Friends, their Fathers: they shall be sure to Mutamus amicos, non r • linqu • m • . Hieron. in Nepot. finde country-men, kindred, acquaintance enough in heauen, that will be Praestolatur n • s Ecclesia primitiuorum: de siderant no • sancti; expectant nos iusti. Desideremus ergò de siderantes nos: pr • p • remu • ad praestolātes nos: expectantes nos votis prae 〈…〉 upemus. Bern. de temp. 98. Vse 2. readie to receiue them, to welcome them thither, to giue them the best entertainment that can be there. Yea this should make vs the rather desirous to die and to go hence, Equidem efferor studio patres vestros, quos colu • & dilex • , vid ndi. Ne
que verò eos solum conu • nire aueo, quos ipse cognoui, sed illos etiam de quibus audiut & legi. Cie. de. sen. that we may goe to, and be with those worthies, whom either hauing knowne here our selues, or hauing read of, or heard report of from others, we haue admired, and desired either to see, or to liue with, while they liued here.

And lastly, if we desire to goe to them when we die, let vs be sure to follow them while we liue. Psal. 119. 63. Adioine thy selfe to them, associate thy selfe with them, while thou liuest here, if thou desirest to be with them, and to partake with them, when thou departest hence. Rom. 4. 12. Walke thou must in the steps of faithfull Abraham, while thou liuest, if thou lookest to haue a place Luke. 16. 22. in Abrahams bosome, when thou
diest, and Matth. 8. 11. sit downe with him, after this life, in the kingdome of heauen. Oh (it may be that some of you will s • y of this our blessed Brother now deceased) that my soule were where his is: that I might be sure to die as he did, and to goe whither he is gone, when I die. Heare what the Apostle saith; he pointeth thee the way, he telleth thee how it may so be, how thou maist haue thy desire. Hebr. 13. 7. Think vpon those (saith he) that haue had the ouersight of you, and that haue declared the word of God vnto you; and follow their faith, considering what the end of their life hath beene. Be not like Balaam, N • m 23. 10. that wished to come where the godly were, but Imp • s & foelix si • simul esse cu
〈…〉 t, V 〈…〉 , ius esse, velit tamen ess • bea • us: Quod nitura negat, 〈◊〉 ratio patitur. De Maeria. apud Iul. Capitol. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Isidor. Pel. l. 〈◊〉 . epist. 168. Bonum quaeris; malum facis; in contrarium curris: quando pernenis? Aug. nom. de Stoic. & Epic. c. 3. had no minde to goe the way that they went. But Hebr. 13. 17. follow the rules that he taught thee, Philip. 2. 17, 20. goe the way that he led thee, by life as well as by lesson, while he liued; and then shalt thou be sure to go to him when thou diest, and to enioy there with him and other the faithfull gone before thee, those ioyes and that blisse, that with God and Christ they are there fully possessed of alreadie.

p.hi: Adde p. 49. l. 9. after, haue beene buried.

div.p:
In regard whereof that Craesus apud Herodot. lib. 1. great King sometime, though then none, preferred
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . peace before warre; for that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . in time of peace vsually Children burie their Parents, whereas in time of warre Parents are wont to bury their Children.
